name: market for orange, fresh grade | orange, fresh grade | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/15688/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for  'orange, fresh grade', in the Global geography.;In this market, default transport model and expert judgement was used to develop product specific transport distance estimations.;The default transport distances are built on a generic model which assigns the transport distances based on the ISIC code. This approach is, especially in case of fruits and vegetables, rather coarse. So in a certain cases expert judgement is used to adjust the default distances.;;The transport distances and associated impacts presented in the markets represents the average scenario for given geography. In case of fruits and vegetables the final impact at the consumer vary a lot depending on whether the food is consumed near the producer or far. The average impact of, for example, banana is overestimated if the consumer is present in Brazil and it is heavily underestimated is the consumer is present in Europe. The markets are modelled so, that editing to model concrete scenario is possible and easy.;;Fruits and vegetables are traded all over the world on an increasing scale. ;It is assumed, that all oranges which are transported are being transported by infrastructure equipped for transport of goods in need of atmosphere control.;;The recomended conditions for transport of orange are (Hamburg Sud, 2013, Stay cool, We care); temperature (lemon): +10 to +14 °C, ventilation (lemon): 15 to 25 m3/h, ;humidity (relative, lemon): 85 to 95%, approximate shelf life (in ambient air, lemon): 1 to 3 months.;Air transport is included for orange, fresh grade and not for orange, processing grade. This decision was made as the literature source for the values of airborne exports (OʹConnell and Mason 2007) refers to "oranges, fresh".;; (OʹConnell,J. and Mason, B. (2007) The Role of Air Cargo in California’s Agricultural Export Trade: A 2007 Update. Center for Agricultural Business California Agricultural Technology Institute California State University, Fresno CATI Pub. #070801. Retrieved from: http://www.aci-na.org/static/entransit/Role-of-Air-Cargo-Calif.pdf, accessed 26th May 2016.);;The product 'orange, fresh grade' is a fruit. It is a perennial crop. Fresh grade represents a product that is meant for human consumption directly.

This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'orange, fresh grade',  within the geography of Global.

This activity ends with the supply of 'orange, fresh grade',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are considered.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/012:Growing of perennial crops/0123:Growing of citrus fruits

exchanges.description:
Estimated value. The USA are the third exporters (years 2000 to 2009) of oranges in the world (FAOSTAT in NOVAGRIM). California represents more than 82% of US oranges production (USITC 2006). The report from Cdfa (2014-2015) California agricultural exports, reports the values in USD, the quantity in ctw, and the quantity by destination of oranges exports for California. The total values exported was of 6.77E+08 dollars in 2013 and 5.74E+08 dollars in 2014 for a weight of 847310790 kg and 661337865 kg, respectively (934 short ton in 2013 and 729 short ton in 2014, where 1 short ton equals 907185 kg). From these values we derive an export values of 1.25 $/kg in 2013 and 1.15 kg/$. In 2006, 980037 dollars of fresh oranges where exported via air (OʹConnell and Mason 2007). Using an average of 2013 and 2014 price, the resulting kg flown are 980037*average(1.25,1.15) = 1.18E+06 kg (0.003% of GLO total production volume of fresh grade oranges which is 3.79E+10 kg, average 2009-2012 FAOSTAT). The cdfa reports destinations for exports to be Canada 24%, EU 1-2%, China/Honk Kong 15-17%, Mexico 1-2%, Japan 12-13%, Korea 23-27%, Australia 4-5%, UAE 0.1-1%, Taiwan 2%, Vietnam 1-2%, Philippines 1%, Malaysia 4%, Indonesia 0.4-1%; it assumed that the airborne destinations are not on the American continent. It is therefore assigned a share of EU 2%, China/Honk Kong 24%, Japan 19%, Korea 37%, Australia 6%, UAE 1%, Taiwan 2%, Vietnam 2%, Philippines 2%, Malaysia 5%, and Indonesia 1%. The distances are calculated using the online tool http://www.worldatlas.com/travelaids/flight_distance.htm. California to EU (Amsterdam as one of the biggest redistributor of air freight in EU http://www.iamsterdam.com/en/business/invest/who-is-here/klm-and-amsterdam-airport-schiphol) 8838.89km, to China/Honk Kong 11458km, Japan (Tokyo) 8646.99km, Korea 9334.77, Australia (Sidney is assumed as destination as it receives the largest air cargo in Australia (Hamal 2011)) 12033.94 km, UAE 13209.29km, Taiwan 10892.25km, Vietnam 12533.4km, Philippines 11677.45, Malaysia 13828.51km, and Indonesia 13219.34km. The total air transport therefore results in 0.001914 ton*km/kg of product (knowing that wet mass of the product = 1). To know more about how to calculate transport for a market activity see the FAQ on the ecoinvent website http://www.ecoinvent.org/support/faqs/methodology-of-ecoinvent-3/how-do-i-calculate-the-amount-of-transport-in-the-market.html.
 
As only exports from California are included this value is most likely quite underestimated. 
 
References:
Cdfa (2014-2015) California agricultural exports. Retrieved from: https://www.cdfa.ca.gov/statistics/PDFs/AgExports2014-2015.pdf, accessed 26th May 2016.
French Ministry of Agriculture and the Statistical Division (FAOSTAT) of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). In NOVAGRIM (n.d.) ORANGE STATISTICS. Retrieved from: http://www.novagrim.com/Pages/2000_2011_orange_statistics_EN.aspx, accessed 26th May 2016.
Hamal, K. (2011) International air freight movements through Australian airports to 2030. Australian Transport Research Forum 2011 Proceedings 28 - 30 September 2011, Adelaide, Australia Publication website: http://www.patrec.org/atrf.aspx
OʹConnell,J. and Mason, B. (2007) The Role of Air Cargo in California’s Agricultural Export Trade: A 2007 Update. Center for Agricultural Business California Agricultural Technology Institute California State University, Fresno CATI Pub. #070801. Retrieved from: http://www.aci-na.org/static/entransit/Role-of-Air-Cargo-Calif.pdf, accessed 26th May 2016.
USITC (2006) Conditions of Competition of Certain Oranges and Lemons in the Fresh U.S. Fresh Market. Washington, DC 20436 www.usitc.gov

exchanges.description:
Transport distance based on US BTS Commodity Flow Surveys 1993, 1997, 2002, 2007, US Dep. Of Transportation, Bureau of Transportation Statistics. 

It is estimated (based on production volumes), that 90% of the transport by lorry is by big lorries which carry a reefer and 10% by small lorries with build in refrigeration machine.

exchanges.description: The total marine transport volume differentiated into major commodity groups based on data from FearnResearch (2001): Fearnley's Annual Review 2000. Oslo: Fearnley/AS, p. 1-78. The category 'Other cargo' accounts for 38% of total maritime transport volume and has been distributed on commodity groups based on the proportions in the marine import and export of the US in 2001-2010.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value.

The reefer operates (is cooling or freezing down the goods) no matter if it is being transported or if it is standing in a port or farm and not moving. The amount of operation of reefer needed is connected directly to different modes of transport using default assumptions on the average speed of the infrastructure.

This exchange represents the time, when the reefer is being transferred from one mode of the transport to another. So for example the reefer is taken by a truck to the port, where it is transferred to a transoceanic ship. During this time the transport vehicles are not moving, but the reefer keeps operating and maintaining the required atmosphere.

Based on an estimate 20% of amount of operation, reefer, cooling is added to cover the time when the reefer is transferred between different types of transport.  So, for example, if the goods stay and is being transported by the different modes of transport for 10 days there are 2 more days added that represent the time when the reefer is being transferred from the truck to the ship and from the ship to the train, etc.
